meanings.definition: To fill (a space) tightly with something.
meanings.sent1: The suitcase was crammed with clothes for the trip.
meanings.sent2: She crammed all her books into the small shelf.
meanings.sent3: The clown crammed too many balloons into his car, making it impossible to drive.
meanings.sent4: The students crammed the auditorium, eager to see the performance.
meanings.sent5: The chef crammed the pastry with delicious cream, making it irresistible.

meanings.definition: To study intensively over a short period of time.
meanings.sent1: He crammed for the exam the night before.
meanings.sent2: She crammed all the information into her mind before the test.
meanings.sent3: The cat crammed for the mouse chase, hoping to catch it quickly.
meanings.sent4: The athlete crammed for the race, preparing both mentally and physically.
meanings.sent5: The detective crammed the case files, trying to solve the mystery before it was too late.
